Description: Egyptian mould-made lamp. Circular base, plain rim, with elongated dots around double groove surrounding fillling hole. Ear-like thumb-piece on right side of rim. Slight decoration on neck with curves in toward nozzle. Inscribed (pre-firing) with Greek letter 'pi'. Nozzle slightly blackened through use. Red fabric, with limited mica. Probably a local Nile silt ware.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parrallel for 'Dolphin type' lamps from Roman Ehnasya (Petrie 1905, 8, pl. 60.26 for body and 72 for neck) cited on Philadelphia register card. Poor 1st century BC to 1st century AD parallel in the British Museum (Bailey 1975, British Museum Lamps I, Q556). But variants of this form are more commonly dated 2nd to 1st century BC (Mlynarczyk 1997, 54-7, later Type A, see Fig. 13). Marked in ink 'ES 114'. 2nd century BC parallel from Tell Atrib (Młynarczyk 2012, type TA 11.2). Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould-made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677. Młynarczyk, J. 2012. Tell Atrib 1985-1995. Vol. 3: Terracotta oil lamps. Varsovie : Éditions Neriton. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1905. Roman Ehnasya (Herakleopolis Magna), 1904. London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.038) (Phase 1)
